title: Design of Experimental Studies and Statistics Applied to Nutrigenomics
text:
0.1 Introduction
Welcome to the repository for the course Design of Experimental Studies and Applied Statistics in Nutrigenomics ‚Äî part of the Master‚Äôs in Nutrigenomics program.
This repository contains all teaching materials, examples, datasets, and R scripts used throughout the course.
The course is fully reproducible and designed to be explored as a Quarto Book published via GitHub Pages.

title: Design of Experimental Studies and Statistics Applied to Nutrigenomics
text:
0.1.1 üìò Course Overview
This course introduces the statistical foundations of experimental design and applied data analysis in the context of nutrigenomics.
Students will learn to manage, visualize, and analyze omics, clinical, and dietary data using R and reproducible workflows.


0.1.2 Topics

Introduction to Nutrigenomics ‚Äî study design and data types

Measures of Association

Data Reading and Cleaning in R

Multivariate Descriptive Statistics

Dimensionality Reduction and Clustering

Introduction to Systematic Reviews

Each topic includes lectures, practical labs, and problem sets.


0.1.3 Evaluation Criteria
The evaluation of the course Design of Experimental Studies and Applied Statistics in Nutrigenomics will be based on three main activities, each contributing to the final grade as described below.

title: Design of Experimental Studies and Statistics Applied to Nutrigenomics
text:
0.2 Description of the Evaluation Components

0.2.1 1. Expositive Seminar (30%)

Format: Group presentation in pairs or groups of three.

Objective: To present and discuss a specific topic related to experimental design, statistical modeling, or data analysis applied to nutrigenomics.

Evaluation criteria: Clarity, scientific accuracy, statistical interpretation, and ability to engage in discussion.

Date: December 4, 2025 (final class session).

Deliverables:

15-minute oral presentation.
Accompanying Quarto or R Markdown document with code and figures (submitted through the GitHub repository).




0.2.2 2. Practices (25%)

Format: Individual R exercises completed during the practical sessions (marked below as Practices).

Objective: To apply the statistical techniques discussed in class using real or synthetic omics, clinical, and dietary datasets.

Submission: Each student must upload the corresponding .R or .qmd file to their personal GitHub fork or send it through the course platform.



0.2.3 3. Final Exam (45%)

Format: Individual written and computational test.

Objective: To assess conceptual understanding and practical skills in the design and analysis of studies in nutrigenomics.

Date: January 21, 2026

Recovery Exam: February 13, 2026

Minimum mark required for validation: 4 (out of 10).

Attendance to all lectures and practices is strongly recommended.

title: 2¬† Overview
text:
2.0.1 What is Nutrigenomics (Statistical View)
This chapter introduces nutrigenomics from a statistical perspective, motivates key experimental designs, and reviews the types of data used in this field. It concludes with practical guidance for setting up R and the course repository.
Nutrigenomics explores how dietary patterns influence gene expression, epigenetic marks, and metabolic outcomes. Statistically, we ask:
Main challenges: high dimensionality (p‚â´n), correlated predictors, measurement error in diet data, and causal inference vs.¬†association.

title: 2¬† Overview
text:
2.1 Basic Concepts

2.1.1 Clinical Study
A clinical study is a process whose objective is to obtain empirical evidence on a specific issue. In the case of the studies we are dealing with in this course, this issue is, naturally, about some aspect of nutrigenomics.


2.1.2 Unit of Observation
In a statistical study, the unit of observation is, for the sake of clarity, the type of what or who is being measured during the research. In medical studies, these are typically people, but not always. For example, they can be events that happen to people, so that the same person can be observed multiple times: pregnancies, surgical operations. For example, we can measure the average daily expenditure on processed food vending machines in different primary schools in a city and the proportion of myopic students in their schools, to estimate whether there is any relationship between processed food consumption and myopia. Here, the unit of observation is the primary schools, not the students.


2.1.3 Population and Sample

Population: This is the set of all observation units about which we want to know some information. This population can be perfectly defined in a place and time: for example, those registered in Mallorca today. But its definition will usually be vague. If, for example, we want to estimate something about ‚Äúdiabetic Spaniards over 65 years of age,‚Äù who exactly are we talking about? Those who are alive right now? All those who have been in Spain since its founding? Do we include those who have not yet been born? What do we do with those who are diabetic but have not been diagnosed, and never will be?
Sample: This is a subset of the population that has been selected for observation. The idea is for the sample to be representative of the population, so that the results obtained from the sample can be generalized to the population. In the previous example, we could select a sample of diabetic Spaniards over the age of 65, and from this sample, attempt to estimate some characteristic of the diabetic population of Spaniards over the age of 65.



2.1.4 Types of Statistics
In statistics, we always start by obtaining data on a sample of a population. Well, actually, we don‚Äôt start by obtaining the data, but by carefully planning how to obtain it.
We generalize the information obtained about this group of people to the entire population. And this isn‚Äôt just a case of fortune-telling magic tricks, but a science whose methodology has been validated through mathematical demonstrations or, in the worst case, through numerical simulations (the mathematical equivalent of experiments in other sciences).
Thus, the starting point when applying statistical techniques is that we have a set of data that describe some characteristics of a group of individuals. Statistical analysis of these data can then be of two basic types:

Exploratory data analysis, when our objective is simply to summarize, represent, and explain the specific data available. Descriptive statistics is the set of techniques used for this purpose.
Inferential analysis, if our objective is to deduce (infer) from these data, significant information about the entire population of interest. The techniques used in this case comprise inferential statistics.




2.1.5 Why Design Matters
Design choice determines causal interpretability and power.

Case‚Äìcontrol (retrospective): efficient for rare outcomes, common in gene‚Äìdiet interaction studies.
Example: Hoang et al., JAMA Network Open (2024). DOI: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2024.0465
Cross-sectional: exposure and outcome measured simultaneously, used for exploratory omics‚Äìdiet associations.
Example: Do et al., Int J Epidemiol. (2021). DOI: 10.1093/ije/dyaa215
Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): causal inference via randomization; typical for genotype‚Äëbased dietary advice.
Example: Horne et al., BMC Public Health (2019). DOI: 10.1186/s12889-019-6621-8

Note: Randomization removes confounding in expectation; observational designs require covariate adjustment and sensitivity analyses.

title: 2¬† Overview
text:
2.2 Design Types

2.2.0.1 Descriptive Studies

Case Report: A detailed description of a patient.
Case Series: A detailed description of a small group of people with a common health problem. Information is usually collected through medical histories and clinical interviews.
Survey: A description of a large group of individuals with a common characteristic. Information is usually collected through questionnaires or interviews. These studies are used to identify interesting observations worthy of investigation.



2.2.0.2 Case-Control Studies

A group of individuals with the disease (cases) and a group of individuals without the disease (controls) are taken.
They are compared retrospectively to find differences in their past exposure to risk factors.
It is determined which risk factors were more common among cases than among controls.
It is inferred that, in the general population, exposure to these factors is associated with a higher likelihood of suffering from the disease.

Case-control samples

Stratified sample: A sample made up of predetermined numbers of cases and controls. If the sample is stratified and artificially composed, we do not expect the proportion of cases in the sample to be representative of the population.
Cross-sectional samples: A sample with no restrictions on its composition, ‚Äúwhatever comes out.‚Äù If the sample is cross-sectional, we expect the proportion of cases in the sample to be representative of the population. Advantages of case-control samples:
The survey suffers from a lack of denominators: a control group with which to compare the cases.
Relatively easy and quick to carry out, and therefore inexpensive.
Suitable for studying rare, infrequent, or very short-term diseases.
They allow for studying the association between exposure to many risk factors and the disease in question.

Problems: Biases
Biases: Errors in the design or execution of a study that affect the data collected and may jeopardize the accuracy of the conclusions drawn from data collection through interviews/questionnaires.

Recall bias: Everyone lies. Forgetfulness.
Differential recall bias: Cases and controls may recall relevant data differently.
Survivorship bias: Only ‚Äúliving‚Äù individuals are studied.

Problems: Representativeness
To conclude that there is an association between exposure and disease, it would be necessary that:

Controls were similar to cases in all aspects except exposure.
Matching: Select controls who are similar to cases in all relevant characteristics.
Controls were representative of the healthy population. Problems: Confounders
Confounder: A characteristic associated with exposure that can cause disease. Disease

Problems: Lack of Causality
A case-control study cannot ‚Äúprove‚Äù that exposure to a risk ‚Äúcauses‚Äù a disease.
In reality:

No type of medical study can demonstrate with absolute certainty that exposure to a risk causes a disease.



2.2.0.3 Cohort Studies

A group of individuals are exposed to a risk factor and a group of individuals not exposed to the same risk factor.
A group of individuals are exposed to a risk factor and a group of individuals not exposed to the same risk factor.
They are followed over a period of time to prospectively compare the occurrence of a disease in both groups.
A study is made to determine whether the disease is more common among those exposed than among those not exposed.
If so, it can be inferred that, in the general population, exposure to the risk factor is associated with a higher likelihood of suffering from the disease.
The objective is to study the onset of the disease after exposure: The cohort must be composed of individuals without the disease at the time of follow-up.

Prospective versus Retrospective Cohort Studies

Prospective

: Exposed and unexposed individuals are taken today, and their future outcomes are studied.

Retrospective

: Exposed and unexposed individuals are taken at a certain point in the past, and their outcomes to the present are studied.


2.2.0.4 Cross-sectional studies
In cross-sectional studies, both the disease and potential influencing factors (or other characteristics) are observed simultaneously in a cross-sectional sample of individuals ‚Äî that is, without a before-and-after component.






Nota



For a study to be considered cross-sectional, it must meet the following criteria:

Cross-sectional in time: The information refers to a single point in time, or at least the passage of time is not relevant to the study.
Cross-sectional sample: The sample is not pre-stratified by the characteristics under study or by variables related to them (i.e., not stratified sampling).






2.2.0.5 Ecological studies
In ecological studies, the variables of interest are measured at the group level (countries, cities, neighborhoods), not at the individual level.
The occurrence of a disease is compared across groups with different levels of exposure.






Nota



Beware of the ecological fallacy:

From an ecological study, nothing can be inferred at the individual level.

For example, we cannot conclude that individuals who eat red meat have a higher risk of colon cancer ‚Äî it may be that the cases of colon cancer occurred among those who did not eat red meat.






2.2.0.6 Interventional studies

Clinical trial: Interventional medical study involving humans.
Randomized clinical trial (RCT): Clinical trial in which individuals are randomly assigned to two or more groups receiving different treatments, and the outcomes are compared. Usually, one group serves as the control group.
Controlled clinical trial: Clinical trial comparing a group that receives a treatment with another that does not receive it.
Experimental study: Any other type of interventional study.




2.2.0.7 Classification by blinding

Open-label: Both participants and evaluators know which treatment each participant receives.
Single-blind: Either the participants or the evaluators do not know which treatment each participant receives.
Double-blind: Neither participants nor evaluators know which treatment each participant receives.
Triple-blind: Participants, evaluators, and data analysts all remain unaware of the treatment allocation.




2.2.0.8 Placebo
A placebo is a substance identical in appearance to the active treatment but pharmacologically inactive. It can be used for:

Blinding the trial: The control group receives something inert rather than nothing at all.
Assessing the placebo effect: Change in the patient‚Äôs response simply due to receiving treatment.
Estimating the spontaneous recovery rate: The proportion of patients who recover without any active treatment.




2.2.0.9 Classification by group formation

Parallel-group study: Different groups of subjects are assigned to receive different treatments.
Crossover study: Each subject receives multiple treatments at different times in a randomized order ‚Äî each participant serves as their own control.




2.2.0.10 Meta-analysis

Systematic review: A summary of all published research addressing a specific question. Patients are not studied directly ‚Äî only previously published clinical studies.
Meta-analysis: A systematic review that uses statistical techniques to quantitatively combine results from previous studies.


Meta-analysis: A systematic review that uses statistical techniques to jointly analyze published results.




2.2.0.11 Pyramid of evidence







2.2.1 Statistical View of Each Design









Design
Description
Typical Model
Key Statistical Notes




Case series
Descriptive report of a group of individuals with a shared exposure, treatment, or outcome, without a control group.
Descriptive or exploratory modeling
Limited inferential power; often used for hypothesis generation.


Survey
Cross-sectional collection of information from a sample representing a population at one point in time.
Weighted regression or complex survey design models
Incorporate sampling weights and stratification; correct for design effects.


Cohort study
Observational design following participants over time to assess associations between exposures and outcomes.
Cox proportional hazards or mixed models
Handle time-to-event data; control for confounding and censoring.


Case‚Äìcontrol study
Observational design comparing subjects with an outcome (cases) to those without (controls).
Conditional logistic regression
Adjust for matching, population structure, and selection bias.


Quasi-experimental study
Design with an intervention but lacking random assignment, often using pre/post or matched control comparisons.
Difference-in-differences, interrupted time series
Control for confounding and temporal trends; weaker causal inference.


Experimental (RCT)
Randomized Controlled Trial assigning subjects randomly to treatments to infer causal effects.
Mixed models or ANCOVA
Power analysis, ITT (intention-to-treat) principle; high internal validity.


Meta-analysis
Statistical synthesis of results from multiple independent studies addressing the same question.
Random- or fixed-effects models
Assess heterogeneity (\(I^2\)); evaluate publication bias.


Systematic review
Structured, transparent literature review following predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria.
Narrative synthesis or meta-analytic framework
Ensures reproducibility and quality assessment of included studies.






2.2.2 Types of Data in Nutrigenomics

Omics data (gene expression, methylation, metabolomics)

Example: EWAS of diet quality ‚Äî DOI: 10.1093/ije/dyaa215

Clinical data (anthropometry, blood lipids, disease outcomes)

Example: NOW Trial ‚Äî DOI: 10.1186/s12889-019-6621-8

Dietary data (FFQs, 24h recalls, dietary indices)

Example: Zheng et al., PLOS ONE (2020). DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0230669


Each has unique preprocessing and error structures (e.g., normalization for omics, energy adjustment for dietary data).

title: 3¬† Variable Classification and R
text:
3.1 Definitions
Variable: A statistical variable is a characteristic of a sample or population that can take on different values.
Although there are many types of statistical variables, in general we can distinguish two main types:

title: 3¬† Variable Classification and R
text:
Quantitative variable: Variables expressed numerically.


Continuous variable: Can take an infinite number of values within a range.


Discrete variable: Can take a finite number of values within a range.


Qualitative variable: Variables expressed in words or numerical codes.


Ordinal variable: Expresses different levels and order. Any Likert-scale variable. Read this blog: What is the Likert scale?


Nominal variable: Clearly expresses a name or category.

title: 3¬† Variable Classification and R
text:
3.2 Introduction to R

R is a calculator (with steroids)
R is an Excel (with steroids)
And what it doesn‚Äôt do, you can program it. These files are known as libraries or packages. For how they work, watch this video.


3.2.1 Basic Filters and Queries
Let‚Äôs perform a filter; we must be careful with logical algebra.

Logical OR operator ‚Äì> |
Logical AND operator ‚Äì> &
Equality operator ‚Äì> ==
Not equal operator ‚Äì> !=
Pipe operator ‚Äì> %>%
True ‚Äì> TRUE (or just T)
False ‚Äì> FALSE (or just F)


#### Logical Algebra

5 > 3

4 <= 6

6 < 6

6 <= 6

4 > 45

4 != 5

3 = 6  ## What happens? (Error: this is assignment, not comparison)

3 == 6  ## Correct comparison

## Assigning objects
## Arrow
x <- c(1,4,5,6,7,86867,7,89,4,5,6,7)

## Equal sign
Alirio = c(1,4,5,6,7,86867,7,89,4,5,6,7)

x^3  ## Not assigned, just displayed

## Creating a new object
y = Alirio^3 

nombre = "Al"  ### Use quotes for names
nombres = c("Al", "Ali", "Car", "Jhon", "Kar") ## Comma-separated

nombres^2  ## Problem: non-numeric values

z = 1:100

## Name <- Operation
y <- z > 7  ## A vector with TRUE if z is greater than 7, FALSE otherwise

y
str(y) ### Structure of y

a = y^2  ## FALSE = 0, TRUE = 1

A = y + 2 ## Adds 2 to every element

## The object 'a' is different from 'A'

title: 3¬† Variable Classification and R
text:
3.3 Applying What We Learned

For this exercise, we will use the data from here
The Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) is a telephone health survey collected annually by the CDC. Each year, the survey collects responses from over 400,000 Americans about health risk behaviors, chronic health conditions, and preventive service use. It has been conducted annually since 1984. For this project, we used a CSV file from the dataset available on Kaggle for the year 2015.
The diabetes_BRFSS2015.csv dataset contains 253,680 cleaned responses from the 2015 BRFSS survey. The target variable Diabetes_012 has 3 classes: 0 = no diabetes or only during pregnancy, 1 = prediabetes, 2 = diabetes. The dataset has class imbalance and 21 feature variables.
Variable descriptions:


Diabetes_012: 0 = no diabetes, 1 = prediabetes, 2 = diabetes
HighBP: 0 = no high BP, 1 = high BP
HighChol: 0 = no high cholesterol, 1 = high cholesterol
CholCheck: 0 = no cholesterol check in 5 years, 1 = yes
BMI: Body Mass Index
Smoker: Have you smoked at least 100 cigarettes in your lifetime? 0 = no, 1 = yes
Stroke: Ever told you had a stroke? 0 = no, 1 = yes
HeartDiseaseorAttack: Coronary heart disease (CHD) or myocardial infarction (MI) 0 = no, 1 = yes
PhysActivity: Physical activity in past 30 days (excluding job) 0 = no, 1 = yes
Fruits: Consume fruit once or more per day 0 = no, 1 = yes
Veggies: Consume vegetables once or more per day 0 = no, 1 = yes
HvyAlcoholConsump: Heavy drinkers (adult men >14 drinks/week, adult women >7 drinks/week) 0 = no, 1 = yes
AnyHealthcare: Have any health care coverage? 0 = no, 1 = yes
NoDocbcCost: Could not see a doctor due to cost in the past 12 months? 0 = no, 1 = yes
GenHlth: General health self-assessment scale 1-5 (1 = excellent, 5 = poor)
MentHlth: Days in past 30 days mental health was not good (stress, depression, emotions) 1-30
PhysHlth: Days in past 30 days physical health was not good 1-30
DiffWalk: Serious difficulty walking or climbing stairs? 0 = no, 1 = yes
Sex: 0 = female, 1 = male
Age: 13-level age category (_AGEG5YR) 1 = 18-24, 13 = 80+
Education: Education level (EDUCA) scale 1-6 (1 = never attended school, 6 = college graduate)
Income: Income scale (INCOME2) 1 = <$10,000, 8 = $75,000 or more


3.3.1 Exercise 1

How would you classify each of the variables above?
Some variables were transformed during measurement. How would you classify them if they were not transformed?



3.3.2 Exercise 2
Review this questionnaire

Classify each variable.
Which variables do not fit in the four categories (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio)?
Are any of these questions sensitive?
Are any questions unclear to the target population?
What issues could arise when applying it?



3.3.3 Working with R
Libraries needed for loading, manipulating, and visualizing data:

readxl: readxl is a package designed for a single task: importing Excel sheets into R. It is lightweight and efficient but does not have advanced functions. It works on Windows, Linux, and OSX, and supports Excel 97-03 (.xls) and newer versions (.xlsx). Formulas in cells are imported as their results. The goal of using readxl is to have tidy data, where each row is an observation and each column is a variable ‚Äî ideal for statistical analysis.
Tidyverse: A data ecosystem in R, consisting of several packages:

dplyr: A grammar of data manipulation providing verbs to solve common data tasks:

mutate() adds new variables as functions of existing ones
select() selects variables by name
filter() selects cases based on values
summarise() reduces multiple values to a summary
arrange() reorders rows

ggplot2: A system for declaratively creating graphics, based on The Grammar of Graphics.
readr: Provides a fast way to read rectangular data from CSV or TSV files and reports parsing issues clearly.




3.3.4 Installing Tidyverse
After installing, load it with the command:

library(tidyverse)

3.3.5 Using Functions to Create New Variables
ifelse allows you to construct categories or ranges from an existing variable with the data already available.
Next, we will get familiar with the ifelse and mutate functions:

## Comparaci√≥n b√°sica

ifelse(5>3, "Bingo", "Next")

## Comparaci√≥n sobre un vector

x = c(1,2,3,6,7,4,3,2,900)

ifelse(x<5, "Bingo", "Next")

The previous operations only display the result, but they are not saved in R‚Äôs workspace.
To save them, you need to assign the result to an object using a name.

datosVege = datos %>% mutate(ComeVegetales = ifelse(Veggies==0, "No come vegetales", "S√≠ come vegetales"))

You can also perform successive operations on the dataset using the %>% operator.
For example, if we want to create a dataset called DiabetesWomen that contains the following variables:

Overweight = Yes: if BMI > 26, and No otherwise.
RiskFactor = Sum of the variables HighChol, Smoker, Stroke, HvyAlcoholConsump
Diet = Sum of the variables Fruits and Veggies
Include only women with diabetes.

We would proceed as follows:

DiabetesMujeres = datos %>% mutate(Sobrepeso = ifelse(BMI>26, "S√≠", "No"),
                                   FactorRiesgo =HighChol+ Smoker +  Stroke + HvyAlcoholConsump,
                                   Comida = Fruits + Veggies ) %>%
                            filter(Sex==0, Diabetes_012 == 2) %>%
                            select(Sobrepeso, FactorRiesgo, Comida)

title: 4¬† Probability
text:
The probability of an event is, basically, a number between 0 and 1 (or, if you prefer, a percentage between 0% and 100%) that measures the expectation of that event occurring.
In this course, we will define the probability of an event as the proportion (the fraction, the percentage) of subjects in a population (or sometimes a sample, depending on the context) in whom the event occurs. This proportion measures the ‚Äúprobability‚Äù that if we randomly select a subject from the population, the event will occur.
Example:

The probability that a coin toss lands on heads is the proportion of the population of tosses that land on heads.

In VERY simple cases, when all possible outcomes have the same probability, this proportion coincides with the fraction of times this event occurs in the set of possible outcomes and can therefore be calculated using the famous Laplace‚Äôs rule: \[
\text{Probability}=\frac{\text{Favorable cases}}{\text{Possible cases}}
\]
For example:

The probability of landing heads when tossing a balanced coin is 1/2 (favorable cases, 1; possible cases, 2; both outcomes have the same probability by definition of a balanced coin).
However, the probability of a child being male is not 1/2, even though there are only two chromosomal sexes. It is the proportion of male children in the total number of all children, which is estimated to be around 51.22%.
Or more exaggeratedly, the probability that a woman between the ages of 17 and 27 is myopic is not 1/2, even though there are only two possible outcomes: being myopic or not. This probability is the proportion of myopic individuals in the population made up of all women in that age group, which, in Spain in 2018, was estimated at 65.4% according to a report by the Visi√≥n y Vida Association.


4.0.1 Set Algebra
Let‚Äôs very quickly review the notations and properties of set operations, so we can use this language in what follows.
Let \(A\) and \(B\) be subsets (in the context of probability theory, they are called events) of a set \(\Omega\) (our population or, in the language of probability theory, the sample space).

\(A\cup B\) is the union of \(A\) and \(B\): the set consisting of the elements of \(\Omega\) that belong to \(A\) or \(B\) (or both).
\(A \cap B\) is the intersection of \(A\) and \(B\): the set consisting of the elements that simultaneously belong to \(A\) and \(B\).

This corresponds to the conjunction of natural language.

\(A^c\) is the complementary of \(A\): the set consisting of the elements of \(\Omega\) that do not belong to \(A\).

This corresponds to the negation of natural language.

\(A-B=A \cap B^c\) is the difference ‚Äú\(A\) minus \(B\)‚Äù: the set formed by the elements of \(A\) that do not belong to \(B\).

Therefore, \(A^c=\Omega-A\).

We will say that \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint, or incompatible, when \(A\cap B=\emptyset\), where \(\emptyset\) is the empty set, the set that has no elements.
We will say that \(A\) is contained, or included, in \(B\), and we will denote it by \(A\subseteq B\), when every element of \(A\) belongs to \(B\). To emphasize that \(A\) is strictly contained in \(B\) (that it is contained in \(B\) but is not equal to \(B\)), we will use \(A\subsetneq B\).

Example:

Consider the population \(\Omega\) consisting of the students in a class, and let \(A\) be the subset consisting of the females in that class and \(B\) be the subset consisting of the students in that class who wear glasses.

\(A\cup B\) is the set consisting of the females in the class or the males in the class who wear glasses (or both).
\(A \cap B\) is the set consisting of the females in the class who wear glasses.
\(A^c\) is the set consisting of the males in the class.
\(A-B\) is the set consisting of the females in the class who do not wear glasses.
\(A\subseteq B\) means that all the females in the class wear glasses.




4.0.2 Some basic formulas
We have defined the probability \(P(A)\) of a subset (event) \(A\) of a population (sample space) \(\Omega\) as the fraction of the subjects in \(\Omega\) that belong to \(A\). From this definition, the following properties follow:

For every event \(A\), \(0\leqslant P(A)\leqslant 1\).

A subset \(A\) of \(\Omega\) cannot represent either a negative fraction or a fraction greater than 1 of the subjects in \(\Omega\).

\(P(\Omega)=1\) and \(P(\emptyset)=0\) (remember that \(\emptyset\) is the empty set).
If \(A\) and \(B\) are two disjoint events, then Thus, \(P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)\).

If no subject belongs simultaneously to both \(A\) and \(B\), then the number of subjects belonging to \(A\) or \(B\) is the sum of those belonging to \(A\) and those belonging to \(B\). Then, dividing by the total number of individuals in the population \(\Omega\) (its cardinal), we obtain that the fraction of subjects belonging to \(A\) or \(B\) is the sum of the fractions belonging to \(A\) and those belonging to \(B\).

More generally, if \(A_1,A_2,\ldots,A_n\) are pairwise disjoint events, then \[
P(A_1\cup A_2\cup \cdots \cup A_n)=P(A_1)+P(A_2)+\cdots +P(A_n).
\]
\(P(A-B)=P(A)-P(A\cap B)\).
\(P(A^c)=1-P(A)\).

That is, the fraction of subjects that do not belong to \(A\) is 1 minus the fraction of those that do belong to \(A\).

If \(A\subseteq B\), then \(P(A)\leqslant P(B)\).

If \(A\) is contained in \(B\), the fraction of subjects belonging to \(A\) is less than or equal to the fraction of those belonging to \(B\).

\(P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)-P(A \cap B)\).

If you want to count how many subjects there are in \(A\cup B\), you have to add those in \(A\) to those in \(B-A\). Dividing by the total population to convert to proportions, this tells us that \[
P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B-A)=P(A)+P(B)-P(A \cap B)
\] where the second equality is due to (5).
For example, if a population is 50% female and 60% nearsighted, and 35% of the total are nearsighted women, then the number of people who are either female or nearsighted (remember, or both) makes up 75% of the population. To the 50% of women, we must add the 25% of nearsighted people who are not women.
The number of subjects who belong to \(A\) but not to \(B\) is obtained by subtracting from the total number of subjects in \(A\) those who belong simultaneously to \(A\) and \(B\), that is, to \(A\cap B\). Dividing by the total number of individuals in the population, we obtain the corresponding equality of proportions.
Example:

Suppose 0.1% of blood donors test positive for HIV, 1% test positive for herpes simplex virus (HSV), and 0.05% test positive for both tests.
What is the probability that a randomly selected donor tests positive for at least one of the two tests? What is the probability that a randomly selected donor tests positive for HSV but not HIV?
Let‚Äôs name the events involved in these questions:

\(A\): Test positive for HIV. We know that \(P(A)=0.001\).
\(B\): Test positive for HSV. We know that \(P(B)=0.01\).
\(A\cap B\): Test positive for both. We know that \(P(A\cap B)=0.0005\).
\(A\cup B\): Test positive for at least one of the two. This is what we wanted to calculate in the first question.

By property (8): \[
P(A \cup B) = P(A)+P(B)-P(A\cap B)=0.001+0.01-0.0005=0.0105
\] The probability that a randomly selected donor will test positive for at least one of the two tests is 1.05%.

\(B-A\): Test positive for HSV but not HIV. This is what we wanted to calculate in the second question.

By property (5), \[
P(B-A)=P(B)-P(A\cap B)=0.01-0.0005=0.0095
\]
The probability that a randomly selected donor tests positive for HSV but not HIV is 0.95%.

Another way to calculate these probabilities without having to remember formulas would be:

Take a population of a specific size as a reference.
Calculate in this population how many individuals belong to \(A\cap B\) (positive on both tests), how many to \(A-B\) (positive for HIV but not HSV), how many to \(B-A\) (positive for HSV but not HIV), and how many to \(A^c\cap B^c\) (negative on both tests), and from there calculate whatever we want.

This method is often called the natural frequency method (‚Äúthe old lady‚Äôs calculations‚Äù doesn‚Äôt sound scientific enough), and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôll call it. Let‚Äôs put it into practice in our case:

Let‚Äôs take a reference population of 10,000 donors.

Why this number? Let‚Äôs see, notice that the proportion of subjects in \(A\cap B\) is 0.05%, or 0.0005. To make the calculations easier, we‚Äôd like all the numbers we get to be whole numbers, so as not to get confused with decimals. Since 0.0005 10000 = 5, it seems that 10,000 will work.

The subjects in \(A\) are 0.1% of the population: 10
The subjects in \(B\) are 1% of the population: 100
The subjects in \(A\cap B\) are 0.05% of the population: 5

In summary: \[
\begin{array}{r|c|c|c}
& A\ (\text{HIV}+) & A^c \ (\text{HIV}-) & \text{Total} \\ \hline
B\ (\text{HSV}+) & 5 & & 100 \\ \hline
B^c\ (\text{HSV}-) & & & 9900 \\ \hline
\text{Total} & 10& 9990 & 10000 \\
\end{array}
\] 1. Then, the subjects in \(A-B\) will be those in \(A\) minus those in \(A\cap B\): 5 1. And the subjects in \(B-A\) will be those in \(B\) minus those in \(A\cap B\): 95 1. For now we have: 5 subjects positive for HIV and HSV; 5 positive for HIV and negative for HSV; and 95 positive for HSV and negative for HIV. In total, 105 subjects. The rest will be negative for both HIV and HSV.
Therefore, the subjects in \(A^c\cap B^c\) will be 10,000-105=9,895.
We obtain the following frequency table: \[
\begin{array}{r|c|c|c}
& A\ (\text{HIV}+) & A^c \ (\text{HIV}-) & \text{Total} \\ \hline
B\ (\text{HSV}+) & 5 & 95 & 100 \\ \hline
B^c\ (\text{HSV}-) & 5 & 9895 & 9900 \\ \hline
\text{Total} & 10& 9990 & 10000 \\
\end{array}
\]
And now, by changing ‚Äúprobability‚Äù to ‚Äúproportion,‚Äù we can calculate whatever we want.

What is the proportion of subjects who test positive for a given test?

There are 105 subjects in the table who test positive for some test: the 10 who are HIV positive and the 95 who are HSV positive and HIV negative. Therefore, their proportion is 105/10000 = 0.0105.

What is the proportion of subjects who test positive for HSV but not HIV?

There are 95 subjects in the table who test positive for HSV and HIV negative, so their proportion is 95/10000 = 0.0095.

title: 5¬† Odds
text:
5.0.1 Conditional Probability
In some contexts, probabilities are presented in the form of odds. The most common translation in Spanish is momios, but others are used: posibilidades, oportunidades, oportunidades‚Ä¶ Here we will use odds.
The odds of an event \(A\) are \[
\text{Odds}(A)=\frac{P(A)}{P(A^c)}=\frac{P(A)}{1-P(A)}
\] and therefore tell us how many times more likely \(A\) is than ‚Äúnot \(A\)‚Äù.
If \(\text{Odds}(A)=q\), it means that for every time ‚Äúnot \(A\)‚Äù occurs, \(A\) occurs \(q\) times. For example, if the odds of failing a subject are 2/3, it means that:
Since they are a quotient of two probabilities, the odds of an event are always greater than or equal to 0 and can take any value between 0 and \(\infty\), inclusive.
Exercise If we roll a balanced 10-sided die numbered from 0 to 9:
If we know the odds of \(A\), we can calculate the probability \(P(A)\): \[
\begin{array}{rl}
\text{Odds}(A)=\dfrac{P(A)}{1-P(A)}\!\!\!\! & \Longrightarrow \text{Odds}(A)-\text{Odds}(A)P(A)=P(A)\\
& \Longrightarrow P(A)=\dfrac{\text{Odds}(A)}{1+\text{Odds}(A)}
\end{array}
\]
Therefore, two events have the same probability if, and only if, they have the same odds.
Note that the function \[
x\mapsto\frac{x}{1+x}
\] is increasing in \(x\):
Since this is the function that transforms \(\text{Odds}(A)\) into \(P(A)\), we deduce that \[
\text{Odds}(A)>\text{Odds}(B)\Longleftrightarrow P(A)>P(B)
\]
As we will see, the correct way to present the results in case-control studies is in the form of odds ratios. The odds ratio of two events \(A\) and \(B\) is the quotient of their odds: \[
\text{OR}(A,B)=\frac{\text{Odds}(A)}{\text{Odds}(B)}
\] That is, \(\text{OR}(A,B)\) tells us how many times greater (or less) the odds of \(A\) are than those of \(B\). Its value is difficult to interpret in terms of probabilities except for its relationship to 1:
But for example \[
\text{OR}(A,B)=2 \Longleftrightarrow \text{Odds}(A)= 2\cdot \text{Odds}(B) \hspace{1.2ex}
\not\hspace{-1.2ex}\Longleftrightarrow P(A)=
2\cdot P(B)
\]
Given two events \(A\) and \(B\), with \(P(A)>0\), the probability of \(B\) conditioned on \(A\) is \[
P(B|A)=\frac{P(A\cap B)}{P(A)}
\]
This value represents the fraction of the subjects in \(A\) that belong to \(B\); that is, it is the probability that if \(A\) occurs, then \(B\) also occurs.
Exercise:
At a university, students are distributed as follows by type of study and gender: \[
\begin{array}{r|c|c|c|c|c}
\text{Study} & \text{Science} & \text{Law} & \text{Education} & \text{Others} & \text{Total}\\ \hline
\text{Men} & 1200 & 1300 & 300 & 2000 & 4800\\ \hline
\text{Women} & 1400 & 600 & 1600 & 1600 & 5200\\ \hline
\text{Total} & 2600 & 1900 & 1900 & 3600 & 10000\\
\end{array}
\]
If I choose a student at random, what is the probability that:

title: 5¬† Odds
text:
6.1 Example in R

# Contingency table: Glasses vs Gender

title: 9¬† Principal component Analysis
text:
9.1 Introduction
Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical method designed to transform a set of possibly correlated variables into a new set of orthogonal (uncorrelated) variables called principal components. Each principal component represents a linear combination of the original variables and is constructed in such a way that it captures as much of the total variance in the data as possible. The first principal component accounts for the maximum amount of variability, the second captures the next highest amount under the constraint of being orthogonal to the first, and so on.
The primary purpose of PCA is dimensionality reduction: by retaining only the first few components, one can approximate the original data while minimizing information loss. This facilitates visualization, pattern recognition, and noise reduction, especially in high-dimensional datasets where interpretation is otherwise difficult. The method assumes that the most meaningful structure of the data lies in the directions of greatest variance, thus replacing the original coordinate system with one defined by these new axes of variation.
Mathematically, PCA can be obtained through the eigendecomposition of the covariance or correlation matrix of the variables, or equivalently through singular value decomposition of the data matrix. The resulting eigenvalues indicate the amount of variance explained by each component, and the corresponding eigenvectors define the loadings that relate components to the original variables. Interpreting PCA typically involves analyzing the loadings to understand which variables contribute most to each component, and the scores to explore how observations are positioned within the new reduced space.
In applied research, PCA serves as both an exploratory and a preprocessing tool. It reveals latent structures, mitigates multicollinearity, and prepares data for further modeling. As Jolliffe (2002) notes, PCA is not only a method of reduction but also a lens through which the essential geometry of multivariate data becomes interpretable.
Reference:
Jolliffe, I. T. (2002). Principal Component Analysis (2nd ed.). Springer Series in Statistics.

title: 9¬† Principal component Analysis
text:
9.2 Example
This document performs a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on the combined data from the anthropometrics.csv and vital_signs.csv files (only visit == 3), as requested. It includes:

Correlation matrix.
Standardization of variables (explanation and effect).
PCA calculation and extraction of eigenvalues.
Scree plot.
Correlation circle (variables on the plane of the first two components).
Biplot (individuals and variables).
Correlation plots between each variable and the principal components.

The tables with the eigenvalues and the proportion of variance explained are shown at the end.

Note: Adjust the file paths if your project uses a different location. The code here assumes that the CSV files are in C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/... as in your example.

title: 9¬† Principal component Analysis
section: 9.3 0. Data loading and creation of the Total object

9.3 0. Data loading and creation of the Total object

anthropometrics <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS1_AnthropometricMeasurements/anthropometrics.csv")
vital_signs <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS6_VitalSigns/vital_signs.csv")

Total <- anthropometrics %>%
  left_join(vital_signs, by = c("id", "visit")) %>%
  filter(visit == 3) %>%
  na.omit()

# Conservamos id por separado y preparamos la matriz para PCA
ids <- Total$id
Total_pca <- Total %>% select(-id, -visit, -period)  # quitar identificadores

title: 9¬† Principal component Analysis
text:
9.5 2. Data Standardization

# En PCA se suele estandarizar (media 0, sd 1) cuando las variables est√°n en distintas escalas
scaled_data <- scale(num_vars)

What standardization does and why:
Standardizing (subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation) places all variables on the same scale. Without standardization, variables with large units (e.g., weight in grams) will dominate the principal components simply because of their scale. With scale(), each variable contributes according to its correlation, not its magnitude.

title: 9¬† Principal component Analysis
text:
9.6 3. PCA and Eigenvalue Extraction

# Usaremos prcomp con centered = TRUE y scale. = FALSE porque ya estandarizamos
pca_res <- prcomp(scaled_data, center = TRUE, scale. = FALSE)

# Autovalores: para prcomp, las sdev^2 son los eigenvalues
eigenvalues <- (pca_res$sdev)^2
var_explained <- eigenvalues / sum(eigenvalues)

eigen_table <- tibble(PC = paste0("PC", 1:length(eigenvalues)),
                      Eigenvalue = round(eigenvalues, 4),
                      Variance = round(var_explained, 4),
                      `Cumulative variance` = round(cumsum(var_explained), 4))

kable(eigen_table, caption = "Valores propios (autovalues) y varianza explicada")

text:
9.7 4. Scree plot

fviz_screeplot(pca_res, addlabels = TRUE, ylim = c(0, 50))








Interpretation: The graph shows the variance (in %) explained by each component. Look for the ‚Äúelbow‚Äù or use the cumulative variance to decide how many components to retain.

title: 9¬† Principal component Analysis
text:
9.8 5. Circle of Correlations (Variables)

# Usando factoextra para el c√≠rculo de correlaciones
fviz_pca_var(pca_res,
             col.var = "contrib", # color por contribuci√≥n
             gradient.cols = c("blue", "yellow", "red"),
             repel = TRUE,
             labelsize = 4)








What it shows: Each vector represents the correlation between the original variable and its components. Long vectors and those close to the perimeter have a high correlation with the components; vectors close to the X or Y axis are primarily correlated with PC1 or PC2.

title: 10¬† Principal component Analysis (joint some databases)
text:
10.1 Example
Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical method designed to transform a set of possibly correlated variables into a new set of orthogonal (uncorrelated) variables called principal components. Each principal component represents a linear combination of the original variables and is constructed in such a way that it captures as much of the total variance in the data as possible. The first principal component accounts for the maximum amount of variability, the second captures the next highest amount under the constraint of being orthogonal to the first, and so on.
The primary purpose of PCA is dimensionality reduction: by retaining only the first few components, one can approximate the original data while minimizing information loss. This facilitates visualization, pattern recognition, and noise reduction, especially in high-dimensional datasets where interpretation is otherwise difficult. The method assumes that the most meaningful structure of the data lies in the directions of greatest variance, thus replacing the original coordinate system with one defined by these new axes of variation.
Mathematically, PCA can be obtained through the eigendecomposition of the covariance or correlation matrix of the variables, or equivalently through singular value decomposition of the data matrix. The resulting eigenvalues indicate the amount of variance explained by each component, and the corresponding eigenvectors define the loadings that relate components to the original variables. Interpreting PCA typically involves analyzing the loadings to understand which variables contribute most to each component, and the scores to explore how observations are positioned within the new reduced space.
In applied research, PCA serves as both an exploratory and a preprocessing tool. It reveals latent structures, mitigates multicollinearity, and prepares data for further modeling. As Jolliffe (2002) notes, PCA is not only a method of reduction but also a lens through which the essential geometry of multivariate data becomes interpretable.
Reference:
Jolliffe, I. T. (2002). Principal Component Analysis (2nd ed.). Springer Series in Statistics.
This document performs a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on the combined data from the anthropometrics.csv and vital_signs.csv files (only visit == 3), as requested. It includes:
The tables with the eigenvalues and the proportion of variance explained are shown at the end.

section: 10.2 0. Data loading and creation of the Total object

10.2 0. Data loading and creation of the Total object

anthropometrics <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS1_AnthropometricMeasurements/anthropometrics.csv")
vital_signs <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS6_VitalSigns/vital_signs.csv")
lifestyle <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS2_LifestyleHealth/lifestyle.csv")
biomarkers <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS4_Biomarkers/biomarkers.csv")
OSQ <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS8_SleepActivity/OviedoSleepQuestionnaire.csv")
IPAQ <- read_csv("C:/Users/UIB/Downloads/AI4FoodDB/DS7_PhysicalActivity/IPAQ.csv")


Total <- anthropometrics %>%
  full_join(vital_signs, by = c("id", "visit")) %>%
  full_join(lifestyle, by = c("id")) %>%
  full_join(biomarkers, by = c("id", "visit")) %>%
  full_join(OSQ, by = c("id", "visit")) %>%
  full_join(IPAQ, by = c("id", "visit"))

Vamos a tomar de los porcentajes, el maximo Y del BMI el promedio

Total_resum = Total %>% 
  group_by(id) %>% 
  summarise(fat_mass_perc = max(fat_mass_perc, na.rm=TRUE),
            bmi_kg_m2 = mean(bmi_kg_m2, na.rm=TRUE),
            baso_10e3_ul = mean(baso_10e3_ul, na.rm=TRUE),
            meancurrent_weight_kg = mean(current_weight_kg, na.rm=TRUE),
            sdweight = sd(current_weight_kg, na.rm=TRUE))


# 1Ô∏è‚É£ Funci√≥n para limpiar valores "<x"
clean_numeric <- function(x) {
  x <- trimws(x)  # quitar espacios
  x <- ifelse(grepl("^<", x),
              as.numeric(sub("<", "", x)) / 2,  # reemplazar <x por x/2
              x)
  suppressWarnings(as.numeric(x))  # convertir a num√©rico (NA si no se puede)
}

# 3Ô∏è‚É£ Detectar variables que deber√≠an ser num√©ricas pero est√°n como character
# 4Ô∏è‚É£ Excluir las columnas de identificaci√≥n
# 3Ô∏è‚É£ Detectar columnas de texto que contienen n√∫meros con "<"
char_vars <- names(Total)[sapply(Total, is.character)]


char_vars <- setdiff(char_vars, c("id", "visit", "defecation", "alcohol",
                                  "exercise", "categorical_score"))

# 5Ô∏è‚É£ Convertir solo las columnas problem√°ticas
Total <- Total %>%
  mutate(across(all_of(char_vars), clean_numeric))

# 5Ô∏è‚É£ Promediar por individuo y visita
Total_mean <- Total %>%
  group_by(id) %>%
  summarise(across(where(is.numeric), ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE)), .groups = "drop")


# 1Ô∏è‚É£ Separar variables de identificaci√≥n
id_vars <- Total_mean %>% select(id, visit)
num_vars <- Total_mean %>% select(-id, -visit, -period, 
                                  -cigarettes_day, -cigars_day, -pipe_day,
                                  -others_psychological)

# 2Ô∏è‚É£ Aplicar imputaci√≥n por kNN (por defecto k = 5)
set.seed(123)
num_imputed <- VIM::kNN(num_vars, k = 5, imp_var = FALSE)

# 3Ô∏è‚É£ Reconstruir el dataset completo
Total_imputed <- bind_cols(id_vars, num_imputed)

# 4Ô∏è‚É£ Revisar resultado
#summary(Total_imputed)


# Conservamos id por separado y preparamos la matriz para PCA
ids <- Total$id
Total_pca <- num_imputed

# Comprobar dimensiones
cat("Dimensiones (filas, columnas):", dim(Total_pca)[1], ",", dim(Total_pca)[2], "\n")

text:
10.4 2. Data Standardization

# En PCA se suele estandarizar (media 0, sd 1) cuando las variables est√°n en distintas escalas
scaled_data <- scale(Total_pca[names(Total_pca)%in%selected_vars])

What standardization does and why:
Standardizing (subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation) places all variables on the same scale. Without standardization, variables with large units (e.g., weight in grams) will dominate the principal components simply because of their scale. With scale(), each variable contributes according to its correlation, not its magnitude.
crumbs: 10¬† Principal component Analysis (joint some databases)

title: 10¬† Principal component Analysis (joint some databases)
text:
10.5 3. PCA and Eigenvalue Extraction

# Usaremos prcomp con centered = TRUE y scale. = FALSE porque ya estandarizamos
pca_res <- prcomp(scaled_data, center = TRUE, scale. = FALSE)

# Autovalores: para prcomp, las sdev^2 son los eigenvalues
eigenvalues <- (pca_res$sdev)^2
var_explained <- eigenvalues / sum(eigenvalues)

eigen_table <- tibble(PC = paste0("PC", 1:length(eigenvalues)),
                      Eigenvalue = round(eigenvalues, 4),
                      Variance = round(var_explained, 4),
                      `Cumulative variance` = round(cumsum(var_explained), 4))

kable(eigen_table, caption = "Valores propios (autovalues) y varianza explicada")

             col.var = "contrib", # color por contribuci√≥n
             gradient.cols = c("blue", "yellow", "red"),

What it shows: Each vector represents the correlation between the original variable and its components. Long vectors and those close to the perimeter have a high correlation with the components; vectors close to the X or Y axis are primarily correlated with PC1 or PC2.

title: 11¬† Introduction to Clustering
text:
11.1 Common Types of Clustering
Clustering is a data analysis technique whose objective is to group similar observations into clusters, such that:
In other words, clustering seeks to discover hidden structures in the data without the need for prior labeling (unsupervised learning).

title: 11¬† Introduction to Clustering
text:
Hierarchical Clustering: constructs a hierarchy of groups represented by a dendrogram. It can be:


Agglomerative: each observation starts in its own cluster and they are progressively joined together.
Divisive: it starts with a single cluster that is then divided.


Partition-based clustering: for example, K-means, which divides the data into a fixed number of clusters, optimizing the internal distance.

title: 11¬† Introduction to Clustering
text:
11.2 Distance between individuals
The distance between individuals is a numerical measure of how different two observations are.
The most common are:

Euclidean distance: [ d(x_i, x_j) = ]
Manhattan distance:

[ d(x_i, x_j) = {k=1}^p |x{ik} - x_{jk}| ]
Where (x_i, x_j) are vectors of the variables of individuals (i) and (j).

title: 11¬† Introduction to Clustering
text:
11.3 Distance between clusters
In hierarchical clustering, the distance between clusters is defined according to a linkage method, such as:

Single linkage: minimum distance between elements of both clusters.
Complete linkage: maximum distance between elements of both clusters.
Average linkage: average of all pairwise distances.
Ward: minimizes the total variance within each cluster.

title: 11¬† Introduction to Clustering
text:
11.5 1. Distance matrix
We calculate Euclidean distances between individuals, which quantify how far apart they are in multidimensional space.

dist_matrix <- as.matrix(dist(num_scaled, method = "euclidean"))

# Heatmap de las distancias
Heatmap(dist_matrix,
        name = "Distance",
        show_row_names = FALSE,
        show_column_names = TRUE,
        cluster_rows = TRUE,
        cluster_columns = TRUE,
        column_names_gp = gpar(fontsize = 8),
        col = colorRamp2(c(min(dist_matrix), mean(dist_matrix), max(dist_matrix)), 
                         c("blue", "white", "red")),
        heatmap_legend_param = list(title = "Distance"))

title: 11¬† Introduction to Clustering
text:
11.6 Dendrograma
hclust performs hierarchical clustering, merging individuals step by step according to Ward‚Äôs criterion, which minimizes the total within-cluster variance.
The dendrogram visualizes the merging process: the height of each merge indicates the distance between clusters.

dist_matrix = dist(num_scaled, method = "euclidean")
hc <- hclust(dist_matrix, method = "ward.D2")
plot(hc, labels = FALSE, hang = -1, main = "Dendrograma jer√°rquico (Ward.D2)")









k <- 3
clusters <- cutree(hc, k = k)
table(clusters)

clusters
 1  2  3 
24 47 29 



plot(hc, labels = FALSE, hang = -1, main = "Dendrograma con rect√°ngulos (k=3)")
rect.hclust(hc, k = k, border = "red")









sil <- silhouette(clusters, dist_matrix)
mean_sil <- mean(sil[, 3])
cat("Silhouette promedio (k=", k, "): ", round(mean_sil, 4), "\n", sep="")

Silhouette promedio (k=3): 0.0374
